Text Classifier Part 1: CNN Classifier Using Pytorch

Sep 1, 2018

Estimated read time: 5 min

Intro

Originally I was motivated to replicate the work of researches from the 2016 paper Hierarchical Attention Networks for Document Classification. However, after reading through the excellent posts by Richard Liao, I decide to roughly follow his journey in order to get more familiar with Pytorch. As I have learned, Tensorflow, and by extension Keras, for multiple reasons (not necessarily with user use in mind) have many more resources available. You can read a breakdown for choosing Keras over PyTorch Here. For me, however, the biggest reason would be the use-ability of Pytorch (de-bugging is vastly simpler process). Also, it is written in a more Pythonic manner so your code integrates easier with other tasks. As a side note, I’ve noticed that many if not most scripts for this implementation are quit lacking in code comments which makes the coder look better and of course much easier for someone picking it up to implement. I’ve tried to be more diligent in this.

This was also an exploration into TorchText which I also prefer to Keras. It has the usual convenient:

  • Data loaders
  • Batch generators
  • Easy loading of GLove and FastText embeddings
  • Easy loading of datasets (such as the IMBD ratings dataset)

There are base NN frameworks that can be used. A recursive or recurrent neural network or convolutional neural network could all be used for the exact same task.

CNN

Due to the different convolutions not being dependent on each other is one of the primary reasons for speedup. This frame-work is well-suited for sentence classification (however may not be the best for larger corpora) Comparative Study of CNN and RNN for Natural Language Processing. Although due to faster training and therefore faster iteration, many researchers have found performance losses are negligible.

Loss Function:

$l(x,y) == L = $

Dataset

From the UCI Machine Learning Repository Here. Although the dataset has several attributes, I’ll be focusing on patient reviews on specific drugs along with related conditions.

Code

Initialize TorchText Data Parameters

import spacy
import torchtext
nlp = spacy.load('en_core_web_md')

def spacy_tokenizer(text): # create a tokenizer function

    return [tok.text.lower() for tok in nlp.tokenizer(str(text))]

# Define a Field class: this is a class that contains information on how you want the data preprocessed.
TEXT = torchtext.data.Field(sequential=True,
                            tokenize=spacy_tokenizer,
                            batch_first=True,
                            fix_length=400,
                            include_lengths=True,
                            lower=True
                           )
LABEL = torchtext.data.Field(sequential=False,
                             is_target=True,
                            # use_vocab=False
                            )

Create word vectors

TEXT.build_vocab(train_data,test_data, vectors=GloVe(name='6B', dim=100), unk_init=torch.nn.init.xavier_uniform_) # fills in uniform for unknown words
LABEL.build_vocab(train_data,test_data)

print ("Length of Text Vocabulary: " + str(len(TEXT.vocab)))
print ("Vector size of Text Vocabulary: ", TEXT.vocab.vectors.size())
print ("Label Length: " + str(len(LABEL.vocab)))
